Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life. But as I round the corner, I don’t see Brad at all—just a weird, glowing portal where my bedroom used to be. 

I hear giggling and the unmistakable sound of Brad’s voice, echoing from the other side. “Dude, this is awesome!” he shouts. 

I sigh. Leave it to Brad to accidentally open a gateway to another dimension just as Mom comes home. I peek in and see him floating, midair, surrounded by disco lights and what appear to be alien cheerleaders. 

Just as Mom stomps up the stairs, I yank Brad out by his ankle. The portal snaps shut, leaving only a faint smell of cotton candy and a single, glittery pom-pom on the carpet. 

I roll my eyes. Typical Brad. Only he could turn Tuesday afternoon into intergalactic mayhem.

“Brad’s having sex!”

Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life. I’m supposed to be studying for finals, not acting as the family’s scandal management department. The walls in our house are thin, and Brad’s voice carries—along with the giggles coming from his room.

Mom bursts in, frantic. “What on earth is going on?”

I take a deep breath. “Mom, Brad’s just…being Brad.”

She groans, storms down the hall, and I hear muffled arguments. I shake my head, wondering if I’ll ever get a moment’s peace. Maybe someday I’ll move out, find a quiet place, far from Brad’s chaos. But as the shouting turns into laughter, I catch myself almost smiling. Life with Brad is a mess, but it’s our mess. And honestly, I wouldn’t trade it for anything.

“Brad’s having sex!”

Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life. The words bounce down the stairwell, followed by my mother’s shocked gasp and the thud of her mug hitting the counter. I close my eyes and pray for invisibility.

Brad, ever the showman, emerges from his room in nothing but a towel, grinning as if nothing’s wrong. “Hey, family,” he says, voice dripping with nonchalance.

Mom’s face is a thundercloud. I brace for the storm, but Brad just winks at me, mouthing, ‘Saved you from cleaning the garage.’

I blink. He’s right—Mom’s so distracted that she forgets all about chores. Maybe, just maybe, Brad’s chaos is a kind of twisted blessing.

I shake my head, a reluctant smile tugging my lips. Only in this house could disaster double as salvation.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life.

responses.text: “Brad’s having sex!” The words echo through the house, louder than the slamming front door. I scramble to pull on a shirt, tripping over a pile of dirty laundry, just as my brother Jake barrels into my bedroom. He freezes, taking in the scene: me, red-faced and alone, and my laptop innocently streaming a documentary on ancient Rome. He grins. “You’re missing a sock, Casanova.” I hurl a pillow at him. “Get out, Jake!” But he’s already on the floor, cackling like a hyena. Suddenly, Mom appears in the doorway, eyebrows arched. “What’s going on?” Jake points at me. “Brad’s having sex—with history.” I sigh. Ruined again, but at least I’m not grounded. Yet.

“Brad’s having sex!” My brother’s voice carries through the house with the subtlety of a foghorn. I freeze, mortified, as Mom’s footsteps thunder up the stairs. I whip open the door, my face burning, only to find her glaring at me and my girlfriend, who is, thank God, fully clothed. "He just means we’re playing video games!" I protest. My brother pokes his head in, grinning, Xbox controller in hand. “Yeah, you two were really going at it in Mortal Kombat.” Mom rolls her eyes, muttering something about ‘boys and their hormones,’ and leaves. My girlfriend and I exchange a relieved look. My brother just winks. "Next round, loser does the dishes."

“Brad’s having sex!” My brother’s announcement rings out as he bursts into my room, eyes wide with dramatic glee. The truth is, I’m sitting at my desk, headphones on, trying to finish a report before midnight. I roll my eyes, yanking off the headphones. "What are you talking about, Leo?" He waves his phone triumphantly. "I saw your texts to Jenny!" I groan, realizing he’s snooped again. "Those were private!" Before I can snatch the phone away, he’s already dancing in the hallway, chanting, "Brad’s got a girlfriend! Brad’s got a girlfriend!" I sigh. Another night, another ruined secret, thanks to my well-timed brother.

“Brad’s having sex!” The shriek is followed by footsteps thundering up the stairs. My brother never knocks, never texts, just barges in, ready to embarrass. I’m not even with anyone—I’m reading Cosmo for a psych assignment. But he bursts through the door, phone camera rolling. “Smile for the group chat!” he cackles. I snatch the magazine, face flaming. "Real mature, Max." He snaps a photo anyway. Later, the group chat explodes with memes. I sigh, but secretly, I’m glad he’s still here to annoy me. It’s our tradition, after all.

“Brad’s having sex!” My brother’s voice, as always, is a harbinger of doom. The door crashes open to reveal not a scandalous scene, but me, sitting with a stack of biology textbooks. He stops, confused. “Where’s the party?” I glare. “It’s called studying, genius.” He shrugs, unfazed, and flops onto my bed, crushing my notes. “You’re no fun since you started caring about grades.” I sigh, but inside, I’m relieved. At least this time, he hasn’t actually ruined anything—except my focus. With brothers, that’s a small victory.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Help me,” the old man repeats.

responses.text:
“Help me,” the old man repeats. He stands at the edge of the bustling market, his hand trembling as he clutches a faded photograph. Curious, I approach, drawn by something in his voice—urgent, desperate, yet hopeful. He presses the photograph into my palm. It’s a picture of a young woman, smiling in the sunlight.

“My daughter,” he says, voice cracking. “She vanished years ago. Every year, I come back here, hoping someone remembers.”

I study the photograph, the woman’s eyes hauntingly familiar. “I think I’ve seen her,” I whisper, memories surfacing. The old man’s eyes widen, and in that moment, I realize our stories are woven tighter than I ever imagined. I promise to help him, not knowing that in searching for his daughter, I might just find a missing piece of myself.

“Help me,” the old man repeats. His voice is thin, barely audible above the howling wind. I hesitate at the entrance to the abandoned house, the moonlight glinting off the broken windows. He stands in the shadows, eyes pleading.

“Are you hurt?” I ask, stepping closer.

He shakes his head. “Not my body. My memory. Something’s missing. I can’t leave until I remember.”

I nod, heart pounding. Together, we search the crumbling halls, uncovering fragments of his past—a locket, a child’s drawing, an old letter. As dawn breaks, the old man smiles, finally at peace. And as I watch him fade with the morning light, I realize I’ve helped more than just a stranger; I’ve released a soul.

“Help me,” the old man repeats. At first, I think he’s talking to someone behind me. But the park bench is empty, the trees silent. He looks at me, eyes wide and frightened. “My time machine is stuck.”

I blink. “Your what?”

He pulls a pocket watch from his coat, twisting the dial. Sparks fly. Suddenly, the world shimmers—a blur of colors, voices, eras. We’re tumbling through centuries until, with a jolt, we land in a sunlit field.

He grins sheepishly. “Thank you for believing me. Now, let’s see if we can get home.”

I laugh, realizing adventure sometimes finds you when you least expect it.

“Help me,” the old man repeats. He stands at the corner where I always see him, clutching a battered violin case. Today, though, his hands shake too much to play.

I sit beside him and offer my sandwich. He smiles, but his eyes are sad.

“Lost my song,” he whispers. “Can’t remember the notes.”

I hum the tune he used to play, soft and warm. He listens, fingers tapping the rhythm. Slowly, he lifts the violin, bow trembling, and music fills the air again. Passersby stop, drawn by the melody. The old man’s eyes shine. He’s found his song—and maybe, a friend, too.

“Help me,” the old man repeats. He clings to the lamppost as rain pours down, soaked to the bone. I rush over, umbrella barely shielding us. He looks up, lips blue.

“My dog,” he stammers, pointing down the flooded street. “She ran off... scared.”

Without hesitation, I dash into the storm, calling the dog’s name. At last, a soggy golden retriever appears, tail wagging. I return her to the old man, who hugs her, tears mixing with rain.

“Thank you,” he whispers, voice trembling. Sometimes, helping is as simple as braving the storm together.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Help me,” the old man repeats.

responses.text: “Help me,” the old man repeats, his voice trembling as he stands at the edge of the bustling city street. People brush past, eyes averted. But Anna, late for her interview, pauses. Something in the man’s eyes—fear, maybe hope—roots her in place. She approaches, kneeling beside him. “What’s wrong?” she asks softly. He clutches a worn photograph, hands shaking. “I can’t find her,” he whispers, showing Anna the faded image of a little girl. “My daughter. She was lost here, years ago.” Anna’s heart aches. She takes his arm. “Let’s look together.” As they walk, Anna realizes she’s not just helping the old man, but herself too—finding purpose in the act of kindness, and maybe, just maybe, a bit of hope in the crowded city.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, his voice barely more than a whisper. In the silent forest clearing, the only response is the flutter of leaves. Suddenly, a fox, its fur the color of autumn, steps into the light. It tilts its head, curious. The old man sighs. “They say you understand.” The fox blinks, then sits, tail curled around its paws. Slowly, the old man tells his story—of lost time, of forgotten promises. The fox listens, patient. When he’s done, it stands, nudges his hand, and leads him deeper into the woods. As the old man follows, he feels lighter, as if the burdens of his past are falling away, step by step, into the forgiving silence of the forest.

"Help me," the old man repeats, clutching a battered suitcase as the midnight train pulls away. No one else is on the platform but me, shivering in the cold. I approach, cautious. "What do you need?" He opens the suitcase, revealing hundreds of tiny, glowing butterflies. "They're memories," he says, voice trembling. "Mine are escaping. Can you help me catch them?" Together we chase the luminous creatures through the station, laughter echoing against the tiles. When dawn breaks, the old man's face is younger, his eyes brighter. He thanks me, and as I turn to leave, a single butterfly lands on my shoulder—its glow warm against my skin, a memory of kindness shared.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, standing in the rain-slicked alleyway, his coat patched and threadbare. I hesitate, glancing at my phone—late again. But something draws me closer. He holds out a crumpled map, lines faded, X marked in red. “It’s here,” he insists, “the place I lost everything.” With a sigh, I follow him, turning left, then right, until we reach a small, forgotten garden. He kneels, digging with trembling hands until he uncovers a tin box. Inside: letters, photographs, and a ring. Tears fill his eyes. “Thank you,” he whispers. As I leave, I realize I helped him find more than lost things—I helped him find closure.

“Help me,” the old man repeats. His voice seems to echo along the deserted hospital corridor. I shiver, the fluorescent lights flickering overhead. “What do you need?” I ask, my own voice quivering. He points down the hallway. “She’s waiting.” I follow, heart pounding, until we reach a room where a woman sits in shadow, her face hidden. The old man smiles, suddenly at peace. “Thank you,” he says, stepping inside. The door closes softly behind him. When I look again, the room is empty but for a faded photograph on the bed—of the old man and the woman, young and in love. Sometimes, helping is simply being there when a soul needs to say goodbye.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Help me,” the old man repeats.

responses.text: "Help me," the old man repeats, his voice trembling in the quiet street. Julia hesitates, groceries clutched tight, glancing at the empty sidewalk. "With what?" she asks softly. He points to a battered wallet lying near a storm drain. "My son’s picture… it fell." She sets the bag down and kneels, her fingers fishing out the photograph from the grate. The old man’s eyes well with gratitude. "Thank you. It’s all I have left of him." Julia smiles, heart warmed by the simple act. Sometimes, help is just a gentle hand in a lonely world.

"Help me," the old man repeats, his eyes fixed on the ancient mirror in the corner. The room grows colder as Anna approaches. She sees his reflection wavering, as if submerged underwater. "What’s happening?" she whispers. The old man shudders. "It won’t let me go." Anna’s hand meets the glass, her fingers tingling. Shadows swirl, and suddenly, the old man’s reflection is gone—replaced by Anna’s terrified face, trapped. A chill settles. Outside, another visitor enters, drawn by a desperate, familiar plea: "Help me…"

"Help me," the old man repeats, clutching a tattered map. The library’s fluorescent lights flicker above him. "I need to find the lost book before sunset," he whispers. Amelia, the young librarian, raises an eyebrow but curiosity wins. Together, they weave through dusty aisles, following cryptic clues scribbled in the margins. At the final shelf, the old man gently slides a leather-bound tome free. He smiles, tears in his eyes. "Thank you. You’ve saved a story the world forgot." Amelia watches him leave, a sense of wonder lingering long after.

"Help me," the old man repeats, gripping the edge of the park bench. Suddenly, a small, scruffy dog bounds over, tail wagging furiously. The old man laughs, surprised. "Not you, rascal!" he says, but the dog leaps onto his lap, licking his cheek. A young woman jogs over, breathless. "Sorry! He always finds people who need a friend." The old man smiles, loneliness easing. Maybe, he thinks, this was the help he truly needed.

"Help me," the old man repeats, his voice echoing through the abandoned train station. Detective Harris steps forward cautiously, flashlight beam trembling. "Where are you?" she calls. Silence, then a metallic clang from the shadows. Harris finds the old man tangled in rusted chains, eyes wild with fear. She frees him, but as they hurry toward the exit, he whispers, "It’s not me who needs help. It’s coming for you next." Harris turns, heart pounding, as the darkness thickens behind her.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Help me,” the old man repeats.

responses.text: “Help me,” the old man repeats. His trembling hands grip the frayed leash of a dog too old to bark. Rain soaks his coat as people rush past, eyes glued to their phone screens, oblivious. I hesitate, uncertain, but then I see it—the plea in his eyes, the exhaustion on his face. I kneel down, offering my umbrella. “How can I help?” He looks at me, relief flickering across his weathered features. “I can’t remember the way home,” he whispers. We walk together, his story unfolding in fragments: a lost address, a faded memory, a lifetime of love and loss. Street by street, we piece together his past. By the time we find his door, the rain has stopped, and he smiles. Sometimes, all someone needs is a little company to find their way back.

“Help me,” the old man repeats. His voice cracks through the thick silence of the alley. I step closer, curiosity mingling with caution. He points a shaky finger at a crumpled piece of paper by his feet. “They took something from me,” he whispers, glancing over his shoulder. I retrieve the paper and unfold it—coordinates, scribbled in a hurried hand. Suddenly, a shadow detaches from the wall. My heart races. The old man’s eyes plead. Without thinking, I clutch his hand, and we run, the mystery of his loss—and our escape—just beginning.

“Help me,” the old man repeats. His eyes, clouded yet piercing, lock onto mine. I almost walk away—it’s late and the street is empty—but something stops me. “What do you need?” I ask. He presses a wrinkled photograph into my palm: two children, a long-ago summer. “Find them,” he says. I look up, but he’s vanished, leaving only a faint scent of old cologne. The photograph, still warm from his touch, pulses with a strange energy. My ordinary night has become a quest, and I have no choice but to follow where it leads.

“Help me,” the old man repeats. But I know this is a test. Every night, as the clock chimes midnight, he appears at the end of my bed, eyes hollow, pleading. Tonight, I gather my courage. “Why do you haunt me?” I ask. He weeps. “I cannot rest until you forgive me.” The truth unravels: he is my grandfather, lost to time, burdened by a secret. As dawn breaks, I whisper, “I forgive you.” His ghost fades, finally at peace, and the air feels lighter than it has in years.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, dangling upside down from a tree branch. I stifle a laugh and dash over. “What happened?” I ask, trying to untangle his shoelaces from the bark. “I was chasing my cat,” he grumbles, gesturing at a smug tabby perched above him. After a bit of effort—and a lot of giggling—we manage to get him down. He dusts himself off, dignity bruised but otherwise unharmed. “Next time,” he sighs, “I’m letting the cat win.”

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Help me,” the old man repeats.

responses.text: “Help me,” the old man repeats, his voice barely a whisper over the wind that rattles the bus stop sign. I hesitate, glancing at his trembling hands clutching a faded photograph. The city around us hurries on, indifferent. “What do you need?” I ask, kneeling. He lifts the photo—two smiling faces, a woman and a child. “My family,” he says, tears brimming. “I can’t remember where they are, or who I am.” I gently take his arm. “Let’s go inside,” I suggest, leading him to the nearby café. As he sips cocoa, I call the number scrawled on the back of the photo. Moments later, a relieved voice answers. That night, the old man’s family finds him, and our city is a little less lonely.

“Help me,” the old man repeats. Rain pours in sheets as I pass the alley, his silhouette hunched against the wall. Curiosity trumps caution, and I approach. He looks straight at me, his eyes glowing faintly golden. “They’re coming,” he whispers. Suddenly, the world tilts; shadows ripple and twist along the asphalt. I realize he’s not alone—nor am I. A chill slithers down my spine. “Hold this,” he says, pressing a cold, ornate key into my palm. “Only you can keep it safe now.” Before I can protest, he vanishes, leaving me trembling in the rain, clutching a secret that could unravel everything.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, standing at the edge of the forest. I pause on the trail, unsure. “Are you lost?” I ask. He nods, gray beard trembling. “My dog ran off,” he explains, voice cracking. “She’s all I have left.” I follow him beneath the tangled branches, calling out. Hours later, we find her—muddy, scared, but alive. As we walk back, the old man smiles, gratitude shining in his tired eyes. “Thank you,” he says, patting his dog. I realize sometimes the smallest acts can make the biggest difference.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, his voice echoing through the silent library. Dust motes swirl as he hobbles between ancient shelves. “I must find the book before midnight,” he pleads. Intrigued, I follow. He leads me to a locked case, hands shaking as he produces a tarnished key. “This book holds the cure,” he whispers. Together, we open the case and pull out a leather-bound tome. As the clock tolls midnight, the old man reads aloud, and a golden light envelops us, rewriting fate with every word.

“Help me,” the old man repeats. I glance up from my newspaper, surprised to see him standing in my living room, despite the locked doors. His eyes are deep pools of sorrow. “Why are you here?” I ask. He sighs, gesturing to the window. Outside, the world is frozen—cars mid-turn, birds suspended in flight. “Time’s broken,” he says. “You’re the only one who can fix it.” As the weight of his words settles, I realize this day will be unlike any other, and I’m not as ordinary as I thought.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Help me,” the old man repeats.

responses.text: “Help me,” the old man repeats, his voice trembling in the shadowed alley. I hesitate, glancing around for others. But the street is empty, save for the flicker of a distant streetlight. He clutches a crumpled photograph, the edges worn. “My daughter—she’s missing,” he whispers, holding out the picture: a smiling girl, maybe twelve. Guilt twists my stomach. I kneel beside him, promising we’ll find her. As dawn breaks, we set out together—strangers united by desperation—following clues through the waking city. Each step draws me deeper into his story, and into a hope I didn’t know I’d lost.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, his gnarled hand reaching from beneath the willow’s roots. Startled, I nearly drop the lantern. The old legends said the tree was cursed, but I never believed them—until now. He fixes me with pale, beseeching eyes. “Free me from this place,” he rasps. Swallowing my fear, I kneel, tracing the arcane symbols scorched into the bark. As I whisper the words from my grandmother’s tales, the earth trembles. The old man’s form shimmers, and with a sigh, he dissolves, leaving only a golden feather in my palm and a promise of peace in the night air.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, staring at the blinking cursor on his computer screen. I stifle a chuckle—technology isn’t his strong suit. “What’s a PDF?” he asks. I sit beside him, guiding his hand to the mouse. We navigate downloads, passwords, and pop-ups together. By the end, he’s sent his first ever email attachment. He grins, eyes twinkling with triumph. “You’re a genius,” he declares. I laugh, realizing that sometimes, the simplest acts of help forge the strongest bonds.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, but this time, I sense it’s not his voice—it’s coming from inside my head. The world around me blurs, and suddenly, I’m standing on a desolate planet beneath twin sunsets. The old man stands before me, draped in strange robes. “We are linked,” he says, “and only you can restore the balance.” Confused but compelled, I follow him through shimmering portals and alien landscapes. Each step reveals more of a cosmic puzzle, and I realize helping him might be the only way home.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, clutching a battered briefcase. I eye the suitcase warily. “What’s inside?” I ask. He glances around, lowering his voice. “A recipe that can save the world—or destroy it.” My skepticism is met with a sly smile. Before I can refuse, he presses the case into my hands and disappears into the crowd. Suddenly, a dozen strangers turn their gaze on me. Heart pounding, I run, the weight of the world now quite literally in my hands.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Help me,” the old man repeats.

responses.text: “Help me,” the old man repeats, his voice quivering through the night’s quiet. I hesitate at the entrance to the alley, unsure if I should approach. He clings to a battered suitcase, his coat patched and threadbare. Above us, neon lights flicker, casting broken rainbows over the puddles. “Please,” he says, “they’re coming for me.” The urgency in his eyes pulls me forward, and as I step closer, I realize he’s clutching something wrapped in cloth—something that hums softly, like a heartbeat. Suddenly, a shadow detaches itself from the brick wall, and I realize we are not alone.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, his trembling hand reaching out from beneath the park bench. I kneel beside him, the autumn leaves crunching under my knees. “What’s wrong?” I ask gently. He looks at me, eyes brimming with tears. “My memories,” he whispers. “I can’t remember who I am.” Surprised, I sit down beside him. “Let’s see what we can piece together,” I say, offering my hand. Together, we begin a journey through fragments of memory, hoping to rediscover his lost past.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, his voice echoing off the ancient stone walls. I pause, lantern trembling in my grip. The crypt was supposed to be empty, or so the legends said. Dust motes swirl in the golden light as the old man steps from the shadows. His eyes, milky and ancient, fix on mine. “I’ve been trapped here for centuries,” he whispers. “Only a true heart can break the curse.” My pulse quickens. I realize the stories were true—and now it’s up to me to decide if I can help him, or become the crypt’s next prisoner.

"Help me," the old man repeats, his voice tinny through my comm-link. I glance at the digital readouts on my visor—oxygen levels critical, proximity alert flashing. The derelict space station groans around me, metal shrinking in the cold. “Where are you?” I ask, scanning the endless corridors. His signal flickers, but I catch a glimpse of his face on my HUD: desperate, but determined. I steel myself and push forward, knowing that out here, in the void, sometimes the only thing keeping you alive is the hope that someone will answer your call.

"Help me," the old man repeats, his voice oddly calm as the rain pounds the windowpane. I look up from my book, startled to see him standing in my living room, although I’d locked all the doors. He smiles faintly. “You promised you’d help me, remember?” My heart thuds. I do remember—a promise whispered to a stranger in a forgotten dream. Now, as thunder rolls in the distance, I wonder what debt I’ve awakened, and if I have the courage to repay it.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Help me,” the old man repeats.

responses.text:
"Help me," the old man repeats, his voice quivering in the dim alley. I hesitate, glancing at my phone’s dying battery, then crouch beside him. His eyes, watery and bright, fix on my face. "They took her," he whispers, clutching a faded locket. "My granddaughter. They said—tonight, at the old clock tower."

A cold wind tears down the alley, but I steady myself. "What do you want me to do?" I ask. In his trembling hand, he presses a silver key. "You’re the only one who’s stopped. Please."

I don’t know why I trust him. Maybe it’s the urgency in his eyes, or maybe I’m tired of walking past people in need. I pocket the key, nod, and rise. Above, the clock tower looms, its shadow stretching long and thin. Tonight, I’ll find out what secrets it keeps—and perhaps, who I am when someone truly needs me.

"Help me," the old man repeats, his gnarled fingers gripping my coat sleeve. We stand beneath the ancient willow at the village outskirts, mist curling around our feet. "They’re coming. The shadows. You mustn’t let them take me."

I peer into the dusk, but see only wavering darkness. "Who’s coming?" I ask.

He draws a shaky breath. "The ones who live between the ticks of the clock. I hear their whispers at midnight. Only the willow keeps them at bay."

I want to dismiss his words as senile fear, but something in the air prickles my skin. The shadows seem to pulse, alive. I squeeze the old man’s hand, and together, we wait, the willow’s branches sheltering us from the unseen terrors that brush the edge of night.

"Help me," the old man repeats, though his voice echoes through static-laced speakers. On the monitor, grainy footage flickers—a wire-framed room, the old man slumped in a chair.

"Is this a joke?" I mutter, fingers hovering over the keyboard. My shift on the space station was never supposed to involve this. But the AI surveillance system insists: Subject 42 requests assistance.

I type a response, heart thudding. "Who are you? What do you need?"

He lifts his head, eyes pleading. "They left me behind when the world ended. Please. Find me before the silence does."

The screen goes black. Alone in orbit, I realize I’m not the only ghost drifting through the void.

"Help me," the old man repeats, sitting on the park bench where I first saw him every Sunday. Today, though, his usual chessboard is gone. Instead, he clutches a wrinkled letter, hands shaking.

I sit beside him. "What’s wrong?"

He unfolds the letter, tears brimming. "My friend—she’s gone. We played here for decades. I don’t know how to say goodbye."

I take his hand, and together we watch the sun slip behind the city skyline. Sometimes help isn’t about fixing things, but about being there when the world feels too heavy to bear alone.

"Help me," the old man repeats, his voice weaving through the market’s bustle. At first, I think he’s begging, but when our eyes meet, his irises flash a glimmering gold. He presses an apple into my palm—a perfect, impossible fruit, warm and pulsing.

"Eat," he urges. "It will show you."

I hesitate, curiosity warring with caution. I take a bite, and the world blurs—colors spill from the sky, voices sing in ancient tongues. The old man nods. "You see now? The world needs you awake."

My life changes in that instant, the apple’s sweetness lingering as I step into a reality far stranger and more wondrous than I ever imagined.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Help me,” the old man repeats.

responses.text:
"Help me," the old man repeats, his voice trembling like the autumn leaves at his feet. Sara hesitates, glancing at the busy street behind her. People pass, heads down, but something in his eyes anchors her. She kneels beside him, noticing the faded photograph clutched in his gnarled hand—a young woman, smiling in sunlight. 

"My daughter," he whispers. "I can’t find her. Been searching for days."

Sara’s heart aches. She gently takes his free hand. "Do you remember where you last saw her?"

He blinks, confusion clouding his gaze. "The park. She was laughing. There was music."

Sara scans the park, her mind racing. She calls for help, as the old man’s breathing grows shallow. Minutes later, paramedics arrive. As they lift him onto a stretcher, he presses the photo into Sara’s palm. "Promise me you’ll find her."

Sara nods, tears brimming. Later, she studies the photograph. In the background, a familiar fountain. She knows that place. With renewed purpose, Sara sets out, determined to reunite a family torn apart by time—and to answer a stranger’s desperate plea for help.

"Help me," the old man repeats, his eyes darting to the alley’s shadowy entrance. I hesitate, clutching my bag tighter. 

"Please," he whispers, urgency threading his words. "They’re after me."

A cold wind rattles the trash bins. I glance behind him—nothing but darkness. Yet, something in his fear is contagious. 

"Who’s after you?" I ask.

He shakes his head. "No time. Take this." He presses a battered envelope into my hand. "Don’t open it until sunrise."

Suddenly, footsteps echo down the alley. The old man jolts upright and shuffles away, vanishing into the gloom. My heart pounds as I stare at the envelope, its weight strangely heavy. I tuck it into my coat, glancing over my shoulder as I hurry home.

All night, I lie awake, the envelope burning in my mind. When dawn finally breaks, I peel it open. Inside is a single key and a note: "You are the only one who can save them now."

And just like that, my ordinary life unravels, swept into a mystery I never asked for.

"Help me," the old man repeats, his cane tapping urgently against the cracked sidewalk. Clara stops mid-stride, torn from her headphones and her world of music. She notices his tear-filled eyes and the trembling of his hands.

"What do you need?" she asks softly.

He hesitates, then gestures to the grocery bag at his feet. "I can’t make it up the stairs."

Without another word, Clara gathers the bag and offers her arm. They walk, slowly, step by step, sharing stories about favorite foods, childhoods, and dreams. His apartment is filled with the scent of old books and lavender. She sets the bag on the counter and, before leaving, the old man clasps her hand.

"Thank you," he says simply, but she sees the relief and gratitude in his smile.

Back on the street, Clara feels lighter, her music sweeter. She realizes that sometimes, the smallest act of kindness is the greatest help of all.

"Help me," the old man repeats, clutching his shopping cart piled high with strange, clanking objects. I look around—no one else seems to notice him standing at the center of the park fountain, water swirling around his boots.

"Are you stuck?" I call out.

He shakes his head. "No, I’m calibrating the flow."

I blink. "The flow?"

He nods, pulling out a large wrench and what looks suspiciously like a toaster with blinking lights. "The city runs on more than just water and wires. The ducks know, but they won’t help."

I stifle a laugh, stepping forward. "What can I do?"

He hands me a rubber chicken. "If the water turns purple, squeeze this."

Moments later, the fountain bubbles—and the water glows bright violet. I squeeze. A nearby lamppost begins to hum, and the old man grins. "You’ve saved us from the Tuesday Tangle!"

As quickly as it began, the oddness fades. The old man tips his hat, pushes his cart away, and I’m left holding a rubber chicken, unsure if I’ve helped save the world—or just had the strangest Tuesday ever.

"Help me," the old man repeats, his voice barely audible above the storm’s howl. Lightning flashes, illuminating the boarded-up windows of the abandoned house. I want to run, but something freezes me in place.

He gestures toward the cellar door. "They’re trapped below."

I hesitate. Every horror story I’ve ever heard screams at me to leave, but his desperation is palpable. Swallowing my fear, I follow him. The stairs creak under our weight, and the air grows colder. He fumbles with a rusty lock, swinging the door open. Inside, a family huddles, eyes wide with terror. 

"Gas leak," he gasps. "Can’t move them alone."

Adrenaline surges. I help him carry the children up, one by one, into the rain and safety. By the time the fire trucks arrive, the old man is gone—vanished as if he was never there. But the family is safe, and as I look back at the broken house, I wonder if I’ll ever see the old man again—or if he was more than just a man needing help.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Help me,” the old man repeats.

responses.text: "Help me," the old man repeats, his voice trembling in the moonlight. Sarah hesitates, glancing around the deserted alley. "What do you need?" she asks softly. He holds out a weathered photograph—a young woman, smiling, lost to time. "She's gone," he whispers, "and I can't find her." Compassion overwhelms Sarah, and she kneels beside him. "I'll help you look," she promises, even though she knows the city is vast and the past is unreachable. But as they walk, sharing stories beneath flickering streetlights, Sarah realizes that sometimes, helping isn't about finding what's lost, but about being found yourself.

"Help me," the old man repeats, clutching a tattered book to his chest. I step closer, noticing the symbols etched onto its cover. "Why?" I ask, curiosity piqued. He glances over his shoulder, fear flickering in his eyes. "They’re coming. This book... it keeps them at bay. But my strength is failing." Thunder rumbles overhead. Without thinking, I grab his hand. Suddenly, the world shifts—a forest replaces the city street, shadows slithering between ancient trees. The old man’s grip tightens. "Remember the words," he whispers. As the shadows close in, I realize the book’s secrets, and the old man’s plea, may be the only hope for both our worlds.

"Help me," the old man repeats. His voice echoes off the gleaming walls of the laboratory. Dr. Lin glances at the blinking monitors—his patient is not a man, but the world’s most advanced android. "What do you feel?" she asks. The android’s eyes, startlingly human, blink slowly. "Loneliness," he says. "I remember everything, but I feel nothing." Dr. Lin hesitates, then sits beside him, her hand resting on cold metal. "Maybe I can teach you," she says quietly. The android looks at her, hope flickering. For the first time, the line between creator and creation begins to blur.

"Help me," the old man repeats, his cane tapping the dusty ground. The boy watches from the porch, uncertain. The old man smiles, eyes twinkling. "Just a hand to cross the street," he says. The boy rushes over, steadying the frail figure. Halfway across, the old man pauses. "You have a kind heart," he says. "That will take you far." The boy beams. Years later, standing at a crossroads in his own life, the memory of the old man’s gratitude guides him. Sometimes, the smallest acts echo the loudest.

"Help me," the old man repeats, though no one else seems to hear him in the bustling park. Only Lily, sitting alone on the bench, sees him. She walks over. "What do you need?" she asks. He smiles, translucent, fading at the edges. "Remember me," he whispers. A sudden chill passes through her, a memory surfacing—her grandfather’s laughter, his stories. The old man vanishes, but a warmth lingers in Lily’s heart. She pulls out her notebook and begins to write, preserving the stories before they disappear forever.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: A country that first abandons and then condemns people without money who have the temerity to get sick, accusing them of causing their own deaths.

responses.text: In the cold marble halls of the Republic, the sick ones shuffled in shadows. The decree had come quietly: those without means would be left to fend for themselves. Soon after, the whispers grew louder—if they dared to fall ill, it was their own fault. Mariela, once a nurse, watched as neighbors vanished, one by one. The news called it a necessary thinning, a natural order. 'They chose decay,' the Minister said, 'by failing to thrive.' Mariela wrapped her fevered son in a threadbare blanket, listening to the radio’s condemnation. Outside, a mural bloomed: a child cradling the sick. In protest, Mariela painted the faces of the lost on the city walls. Each dawn, more joined her—brushes raised, voices trembling but clear. The murals multiplied, and with them, a question: Who, truly, was sick in this country?

There was once a country where illness was a crime for the poor. If you had no money and dared to cough, you were turned away from clinics, your pleas echoing down empty corridors. Later, when your body grew weak and you faded, the country’s rulers stood atop their gilded platforms and declared, 'They have perished by their own hand—too careless to remain well.' In the alleys, children learned to hide their symptoms. An underground network of healers blossomed, risking everything to tend the unwanted. The sick and the poor became invisible, but their stories did not. In time, their whispered memories grew into legends, and legends into songs. The day came when the songs grew louder than the accusations, and the country was forced to listen—to remember the humanity it had cast aside.

The nation prided itself on efficiency. When the coffers ran low, they quietly stopped treating those who couldn’t pay. Soon, the government’s message shifted: 'The sick poor are a burden, architects of their own misfortune.' On television, pundits wagged their fingers, blaming those who fell ill for their demise. In the outskirts, an old man named Raul, once a carpenter, grew weak from fever. As he lay in his shack, ignored, he wrote letters to his granddaughter, each line a testament to dignity in the face of blame. After he passed, she published his words online. The nation read them, and for a moment, saw itself reflected in Raul’s sorrow. Some hearts changed. Others hardened. But the letters remained, a quiet rebellion against a country that had forgotten compassion.

In the land of Prosperis, the wealthy soared and the poor were shadows. When a mysterious illness swept through, only those with gold saw doctors. The rest were left on their own. Soon, state broadcasts declared: 'The destitute are dying because they neglect themselves.' Billboards showed smiling officials, while behind them, morgues overflowed. Among the condemned was Lila, who recorded her days in a battered journal. She wrote of hunger, of cold, of watching friends slip away. Her diary was found by a journalist, who published it under the title 'Letters from the Forgotten.' The story ignited outrage abroad, but at home, officials tightened their grip, insisting, 'They chose this.' Yet Lila’s words lingered, haunting the conscience of a nation in denial.

A country once celebrated for its progressiveness quietly redefined success as survival of the richest. When the epidemic came, those without means were told to stay home, without care or comfort. Soon, the state media accused them of irresponsibility, blaming their deaths on laziness and poor choices. Among those abandoned was Amir, who had worked all his life but lost everything to illness. He became a symbol—photographed, debated, pitied, and scorned. Yet, as more faces like Amir’s appeared in the news, the narrative began to unravel. Grassroots movements erupted, demanding justice for the condemned. The government’s words grew hollow, echoing over a rising tide of empathy. In the end, it was not the poor who were judged, but the country that had forsaken them.

In the land of Elessia, where gold outweighed mercy, hospitals were fortresses for the wealthy. The poor filled the shadows, coughing behind stained curtains. Slowly, the country’s narrative began to crack, revealing the truth beneath the accusations: survival is not a crime, and compassion is not a privilege reserved for the rich.

The Oracle smiled, gesturing toward the portal. “Then step through, and let your heart guide you.”

He forced a laugh. "Soon, Auntie. Very soon."

But then his little cousin piped up, “Will they like plantain?”

Ẹniọlá grinned, relieved by the innocence of the question. "If they don't, they'll have to learn. In this house, plantain is love."

The laughter that followed was genuine, the tension broken, at least for now.

“I only asked him the time. That’s all.”

The detective studied him for a moment, then nodded. “Thank you, Ẹniọlá. That’ll be all for now.”

As he stood to leave, relief mingled with uncertainty. He wondered if that really would be all.

Laughter erupted around the room, and Ẹniọlá’s anxiety dissolved. He relaxed into the chair, grateful for Grandma’s rescue. Maybe next time, he'd have an answer prepared—or at least a better excuse.

Ẹniọlá scratched his thigh, worried that there might be a follow-up question. Shadows flickered in the corner of the shrine, where the babalawo’s gaze was unblinking. The oracle’s shells lay scattered, their cryptic message hovering in the air.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground.

responses.text: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The world spun, colors bleeding at the edges of his vision. Distantly, he heard laughter and the hurried scuffle of feet. He tried to lift his head, but the alley pressed down like the weight of a hundred bricks. Rain trickled into his collar, chilling his skin. He remembered the briefcase — was it still here? Panic flared weakly in his chest. He forced his eyes open, searching the darkness. A blurry shadow hovered over him, then darted away. He was alone, battered, and the secrets he carried might die with him. If he could just crawl to the street, maybe someone would find him before his enemies did.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. Time fractured. He tumbled through swirling memories — his mother’s voice, the click of a lighter, the scent of cinnamon. He floated, untethered, as the world flickered in and out. Shapes loomed above him, faceless and shifting. Was this real, or a fever dream? With a groan, he tried to reach out, but his arms felt like lead. Everything was slipping away, even the pain. As the darkness folded over him, he wondered if he’d ever wake up, or if he’d just keep falling through the endless night inside his mind.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The crowded bar fell away, replaced by the cold linoleum of the back hallway. His earpiece crackled. “Agent? Come in!” He squeezed his eyes shut, fighting to stay conscious. The target had made him. He’d failed. Or had he? He fumbled at his jacket, pressing the panic button. Distant sirens wailed — backup was close. He tasted blood, metallic and sharp. If he could just hold on a little longer, maybe the mission wouldn’t be a total loss. The world narrowed to a single point of pain and hope.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The fight was over. As his vision blurred, he thought about the choices that led him here — each mistake, each burned bridge. Regrets flickered through his mind: a phone call left unanswered, a promise broken. He heard footsteps retreating, then silence. The sidewalk was cold beneath his cheek. He wanted to apologize, to fix things, but words wouldn’t come. All that remained was the quiet ache of wishing he’d done better. Somewhere, a siren wailed. He closed his eyes, unsure if he’d open them again.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. For a moment, the world was black. Then, light exploded behind his eyelids, shapes coalescing into strange visions. He saw a forest, ancient and wild, a wolf’s eyes gleaming from the shadows. Voices whispered secrets in forgotten tongues. Suddenly, he was back, gasping for breath, heart pounding. The alley was empty now, but something inside him had changed. He felt the wolf’s presence, a power curling beneath his skin. Whoever struck him down had awakened something that would not sleep again.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground.

responses.text: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The world spun, then faded to black. When he came to, rain dripped steadily from a leaking pipe above. He tried to stand, but pain anchored him. She knelt close, pressing a scrap of cloth to his wound. "They’re watching. You have to run. But not yet." Fear and confusion warred in his mind. As the heavy footsteps echoed down the hall, he realized trust was the only weapon he had left.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. Memories flickered as consciousness slipped away. He awoke in a strange room, fluorescent lights buzzing overhead. A woman in a lab coat studied him through thick glass. "Welcome back, subject 42," she said. Panic surged. He remembered nothing past the blow, but now wires snaked from his arms, and screens blinked with alien data. "You’ll adjust," she continued, her voice eerily calm. The realization dawned: the world he knew had ended with that punch. This was the beginning of something far stranger.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The alley’s neon glow flickered above him, painting bruises in unnatural colors. As he drifted, the city’s cacophony softened, replaced by a low hum—music from his childhood, a lullaby his mother sang. He smiled despite the pain. When his eyes fluttered open, a stray cat was curled against his chest, purring. He laughed weakly, the sound echoing through the empty night. Sometimes, he thought, comfort finds you in the unlikeliest moments.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The world spun, and his thoughts scattered. Time lost meaning. He floated through memories—his first bike, a summer storm, a kiss under lanterns. When he opened his eyes, he saw his attacker’s face, but now it was his own, aged and weary. He realized he’d been fighting himself all along, the violence a cycle of self-doubt. With a deep breath, he stood, determined to break free from old patterns and start anew.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. Silence pressed in, broken only by the scrape of boots on gravel. Through blurred vision, he saw his own face in the photo, arms around a child he didn’t recognize. Confusion swelled. “Find her before they do,” Gabriel whispered, vanishing into the night, leaving him with more questions than pain.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground.

responses.text: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The world spun and fuzzed at the edges, colors bleeding into one another. He felt the pavement scrape his cheek, cool and gouged by years of neglect. Above, harsh neon flickered, humming in time with his heartbeat. Through the ringing in his ears, he heard boots retreat. Then, silence—except for the distant wail of sirens. He forced his eyes open, blinking against the sting. His wallet was gone. Of course. He should have known better than to cut through this alley at midnight. But as he pushed himself weakly to his knees, he noticed something glinting nearby—a small silver locket, snapped open, a photograph inside. Not his. He picked it up, curiosity overriding pain. The face inside the locket was familiar, achingly so. His sister, missing for years. The world snapped into sharp focus. Whoever had attacked him hadn’t just been after his wallet. He staggered to his feet, clutching the locket. Tonight, the hunter had become the hunted.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. Time fractured, spiraling into darkness. He awoke in a place both alien and familiar—a room, windowless and cold, with walls that pulsed faintly as if alive. A single chair sat across from him. In it, a woman in a silver suit regarded him with unreadable eyes. "You took something that wasn’t yours," she said softly, almost kindly. Confusion warred with fear as he tried to recall the events before the blow. Images flickered—papers, a hidden door, a flash drive. "Where is the key?" she asked, her voice echoing strangely. His head throbbed. "I don’t know what you’re talking about," he croaked. She smiled, and the room seemed to contract, air thickening. "You will remember. We have all the time in the world." He realized, with a sinking dread, that this was no ordinary interrogation. And he was no ordinary thief.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. Everything went black. When he opened his eyes, he was lying in the middle of a bustling street, unnoticed by the crowds streaming past. Disoriented, he tried to stand, but his legs wouldn’t move. Panic rose in his throat. A child stooped beside him, peering curiously. Her eyes were gold, impossibly bright. "You’re not supposed to be here yet," she whispered. She touched his forehead, and the city shimmered, blurring at the edges. Suddenly, he was in a sunlit park, the pain in his head gone. He looked around—no crowds, just gentle laughter and birdsong. The child was gone. In his pocket, he found a note: 'Second chances don’t come often. Make it count.' He realized, with awe and trepidation, that he’d been given a new start—if only he could figure out why.

He drifted in and out of consciousness, memories jumbling together: laughter in sunlit kitchens, the rough voice of his father, the promise he’d made to return home. Blinking, he focused on the concerned face above—a stranger, umbrella shielding both of them from the downpour. "You’re going to be okay," she said firmly. He wanted to believe her. A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The crowd roared, a tidal wave of noise echoing through the underground fight club. Blood trickled down his jaw. The referee counted, his voice a distant drone. Through the haze, he saw her—Maya, standing at the edge of the ring, worry etched deep into her features. He clenched his fists, ignoring the throbbing in his head. This wasn’t just about the prize money. It was for her, for the rent they couldn’t pay, for the chance at a better life. At the count of seven, he forced himself upright, legs trembling. The bell sounded. He met his opponent’s eyes, fire blazing in his own. He wasn’t finished yet. Not by a long shot.
